title: Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies
Diamond places the development of human society in context, which is vital to understanding the development of medicine
Man and Nature in the Renaissance
This book has quotes from Vesalius, which is very helpful in understanding his work
Science Matters: Achieving Scientific Literacy
A clear and readable overview of scientific principles and how they apply in today’s world, which includes the world of medicine

container-title: Spangenburg, Ray, and Diane Kit Moser. The Birth of Science: Ancient Times to
title: Internet History of Science Sourcebook. Available online
A rich resource of links related to every era of science history, broken down by disciplines, and exploring philosophical and ethical issues relevant to science and science history
The Beginnings of Western Science

A helpful explanation of the beginning of science and scientific thought. Though the emphasis is on science in general, there is a chapter on Greek and Roman medicine as well as medicine in medieval times
A Short History of the World
This helps place medical developments in context with world events
The Ascent of Science
A sweeping overview of the history of science from the Renaissance to the present
A highly readable book with key chapters on some of the most significant developments in medicine
A Short History of Medicine

While there have been many new discoveries since Ackerknecht last updated this book, his contributions are still important as it helps the modern researcher better understand when certain discoveries were made and how viewpoints have changed over time
The Medieval Health Handbook
This was originally published in Italy as Tacuinum Sanitatis and describes medieval cures of the day

note: This book is dated but helpful on the history of surgery.
title: The Early History of Surgery
Source Book of Medical History
Clendening has collected excerpts from medical writings from as early as the time of the Egyptian papyri, making this a very valuable reference work

note: Dary outlines the medical practices in the United States from 1492 on.
title: Frontier Medicine: From the Atlantic to the Pacific 1492–1941
This is a brand-new book that has been very well reviewed
Timetables of Medicine
An easy-to-assess chart/time line of medicine with overviews of each period and sidebars on key people and developments in medicine
The History of Medicine: Medicine in the Middle Ages

A heavily illustrated short book to introduce young people to what medicine was like during medieval times. Dawson is British so there is additional detail about the development of medicine in Britain
Dittrick Medical History Center at Case Western Reserve. Available online
This site provides helpful links to medical museum Web sites
History of Medicine

Though the book is written by only one author, each Further Resources 147 chapter focuses on the history of a single aspect of medicine, such as surgery or pharmacology. It is a helpful reference book
The Illustrated History of Surgery
This is an academic book that is very helpful in understanding early surgery
A Brief History of Disease, Science, and Medicine

Michael Kennedy was a vascular surgeon and now teaches firstand ­second-year medical students an introduction to clinical medicine at the University of Southern California. The book started as a series of his lectures, but he has woven the material together to offer a cohesive overview of medicine
Western Medicine: An Illustrated History
A variety of experts contribute chapters to this book that covers medicine from Hippocrates through the 20th century
A History of Medicine
An excellent overview of the world of medicine from paleopathology to microbiology
The Cambridge Illustrated History of Medicine

In essays written by experts in the field, this illustrated history traces the evolution of medicine from the contributions made by early Greek physicians through the Renaissance, Scientific Revolution, and 19th and 20th centuries up to current advances. Sidebars cover parallel social or political events and certain diseases
The Greatest Benefit to Mankind: A Medical History of Humanity
Over his lifetime, Porter wrote a great amount about the history of medicine, and this book is a valuable and readable detailed description of the history of medicine

note: This book focuses on the personalities behind the discoveries and adds a human dimension to the history of medicine.
title: A History of Public Health
While serious public health programs did not get underway until the 19th century, Rosen begins with some of the successes and failures of much earlier times. 148 The Scientific Revolution
Doctors & Discoveries
A History of American Medicine from the Colonial Period to the Early Twentieth Century
This is an academic book that provides very valuable information about colonial America
United States National Library, National Institutes of Health. Available online
A reliable resource for online information pertaining to the history of medicine

note: Accessed October 31, 2008. Information on medieval medicine with links to other medieval sites.
title: Available online

note: Ryves, W. “The life of the admired physician and astrologer of our times, Mr. Nicholas Culpeper.” Published in Culpeper’s School of Physick, 1659. Available online. URL:
Accessed December 15, 2008. Culpeper was a fascinating fellow.
title: Antoni van Leeuwenhoek (1632–1723).” University of California at Berkeley Museum of Paleontology Web site. Available online
An incisive essay on the scientist’s research from the point of view of his use of the microscope
Daily Life in the Middle Ages
This is a wonderfully thorough book about life in the middle ages, and it describes everything from what they ate to how they fought during medieval times
Migraine
A helpful book about understanding migraines

container-title: Bulletin of the New York Academy of Medicine 46
note: This provides information on Wiseman and surgery. index
title: Richard Wiseman: His Contributions to ­English Surgery
